children.text:
I envision a world
where life is valued, work is meaningful, and flourishing is possible. In the
face of increasing austerity, state violence, economic recession and climate
collapse, the path towards the world I envision narrows: mutual aid is
increasingly essential, and collective action is increasingly urgent. Given
these circumstances, I’m interested in exploring what exactly constitutes a
“collective”: how is it produced, sustained, drawn to action, dissolved? These questions
are as quotidian as they are political. I want to understand (and disrupt,
reconfigure) the rhythm of everyday life under capital in the historical moment
in which I find myself. Here, I explore the role of sound in the production of
social space, using the KAZI 88.7 FM radio show The Morning Grind as a point of
entry.

For the first decade of
commercial radio in the United States, “shows did not have black announcers,
actors, or masters of ceremonies.”

In 1929, the white-owned WSBC
Chicago launched the first radio program to feature all-Black performers, ‘The
All-Negro Hour’.

Following World War II,  Black music,
personalities, announcers, and disc jockeys, proliferated on the airwaves: In
the 1950s, Black radio “fueled the popularity of rock-and-roll and was
instrumental in lowering cultural barriers between blacks and whites.”

Black DJs’ influence on
American music taste “created a social grapevine” that empowered emergent civil
rights movement. “Southern black stations, in particular, became
clearninghouses for information and forums for discussion” among community
members.” Black ownership of stations was (and remains) rare: only five
Black-owned radio stations existed in 1966.

Over the course of the
1970s and 1980s, “industry-wide trends […] de-emphasized the news and public
affairs programming that had become the stable of Black radio. The emergence of
FM radio, with its ‘more music, less talk’ philosophy, intensified the trend
away from news and discussion shows that targeted black audiences.” Still,
black radio stations proliferated and Black ownership of stations increased.
The emergence of the first Black-owned national radio networks in the early
1970s increased standardization across Black radio programming, which mirrored
standardizing trends in public affairs and news programming in general.

It
was in this milieu that Dr. John L. Warfield, professor of African American
Studies at the University of Texas, began to dream of creating a Black radio
station in Austin. With the transmission of its first broadcast in 1982, KAZI
became the city’s first community radio station. Today, the listener-supported,
volunteer-run station preserves its mission:

to
reach and provide educational programming and information with special emphasis
on media access for the African American community and other groups previously
unserved by existing radio stations in Austin.

The character of 88.7’s programming
is more reminiscent of the Civl-Rights era news and discussion shows, which
feature live DJ mixes, informal talk among hosts, call-ins from listeners,
interviews with activists and local musicians, and open criticism of local and
national politics.

For Henri Lefebvre, space
cannot be properly understood with a mere inventory of “what

space.” He sets out to
understand the production of space “by bringing the
various kinds of space [mental, physical, natural, historic, etc.] and the
modalities of their genesis together within a single theory.”

His theory turns on a
central premise: that “(social) space is a (social) product.”

Yet, he laments that this
fundamental nature of space is too often misunderstood, overlooked, or actively
obscured: “to speak of ‘producing’ space sounds bizarre, so great is the sway
still held by the idea that empty space is prior to whatever ends up filling
it.”

The nature of space (as
social, as product, and as social-product) is obscured by “dominant illusions”
which reify or naturalize space and its contents as fixed, immobile, and
eternal.

This illusion may lead
inhabitants of space to take for granted that the space they occupy is natural
or inevitable – a kind of naïve acceptance of space as it appears, which may be
more common in members of a dominant class who are better-insulated from state
violence. At the same time, Lefebvre observes, even critics of the current
economic order have a tendency toward the illusion of fixity:

Some
over-systematic thinkers oscillate between loud denunciations of capitalism and
the bourgeoisie and their repressive institutions on the one hand, and
fascination and unrestrained admiration on the other. They make society into
the ‘object of a systemization which must be ‘closed’ to be complete; they thus
bestow a cohesiveness it utterly lacks upon a totality which is in fact
decidedly open – so open, indeed, that it must rely on violence to endure.

Here we see a contradiction inherent
to capitalist (dominant) space. On the one hand, it’s true that capital’s
demand for extraction leads to the production of space through top-down control:
“The dominant form of space, that of the centres of wealth and power,
endeavours to mould the spaces it dominates (i.e. peripheral spaces), and it
seeks, often by violent means, to reduce the obstacles and resistance it
encounters there.” Yet, on the other hand, the power to dominate can never be
made total: “The social and political (state) forces which engendered this
space now seek, but fail, to master it completely”

The city of Austin is one
such form of “dominated” space. At the scale of the city, global economic
forces find their concrete expression: corporations build a headquarters, rent
increases, highways expand, ICE raids an elementary school, the river is dammed
into a lake, etc. Inhabitants of a city can feel larger mechanisms of power in
real time as they move through social space. It is through the embodied
attunement to that space that reveals its openness: “For it is by means of the
body that space is perceived, lived - and produced.”

Public broadcasts,
while accessible online from anywhere, are predominantly consumed by those within
range of the FM signal.

And, as opposed to the broad
application of NPR shows, The Morning Grind is an explicitly local variety show,
which discusses Austin events, history, culture, and politics. The hyper-local,
daily, and live nature of The Morning Grind makes the show intensely spatial,
despite its aural (and therefore, less-fixed) quality. In one episode alone,
recorded May 2nd 2025, hosts Mikel, DJ Bean, Mz. Marlah, and later
Haris Q, discuss such wide-ranging topics as:

·   
Black
music history (and its concealment/erasure from dominant discourse)

·   
The
federal status of DEI programming

·   
The
closure of historically Black Austin Jazz club the Skylark Lounge

These discussions are
spontaneous and off-the-cuff, but often deeply informative. The Morning Grind’s
multi-generational hosts offer perspectives from their lived experience that
inform both co-hosts and listeners. By nature of the show’s format, discussions
of current events are constantly grounded in historical context and vice-versa:
demonstrating the ongoing, processual nature of history. In this way, KAZI
hosts avoid the mistakes Lefebvre identifies in “some over-systematic
thinkers.” While this episode did not feature on-air calls with listeners,
hosts still request feedback from listeners and make direct calls to
action.

A week after I went to
the Skylark Lounge for the first time, I sat in the digitization lab on 16th
and Guadalupe and listened to the hosts of the Morning Grind talk about the
Skylark Lounge closing down. Through listening to this local broadcast discuss
this venue (space) I had only just gotten to know – I can feel something shift
in my embodied relationship to Austin. In the moment of listening, I can no
longer experience the city abstractly, as a map to traverse. It is a living,
multi-dimensional space of overlap, cohabitation, which I am present in and
beholden to.  Lefebvre might describe
this shift  - from a “map” image of the
city to a more embodied sense of its liveliness - as an instance of “breaking
the illusion of transparency,” the illusion which reduces spaces to mere
symbols, discourse, language. The Morning Grind enables this departure from
language to sonic embodiment.

From its beginnings in
1982 to its present, KAZI has operated on the periphery of mainstream
broadcasting. Yet, its longstanding sonic presence cannot be overlooked as a
product and producer of social space in town. 88.7 FM is an instructive example
of how the dominant techno-space of radio broadcasting can be reappropriated to
serve the needs of marginalized Austinites. The Morning Grind creates a
soundscape within and against conditions of violence that disrupts dominant
forms of (dis)embodiment; a sonic transmission that enables collective memory
keeping, planning, action, and living.
